ygData.subject: Evolution of a Spaceship
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Everyone, I got really carried away playing with Mattias NEAT-based Genetic Art tool, and evolved a spaceship.  I found the steps that evolution went

Subject: Evolution of a Spaceship
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01


Hi Everyone, 

I got really carried away playing with Mattias' NEAT-based Genetic 
Art tool, and evolved a spaceship.  I found the steps that evolution 
went through interesting enough to make a web page chronicling the 
development of the final form:

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/rocket.html

There are a couple particularly interesting things about this.  One 
is that it is quite easy to see how important complexification is in 
introducing new phenotypic features, and that's kind of cool.  
Another is the sometimes astounding meaningfulness of some of the 
features that randomly appear.  But I think perhaps the most 
interesting thing has to do with artificial embryogeny: You can see 
a process of elaborating on a theme, much like what Joe Reisinger 
and I talked about in our short paper "Exploiting Morphological 
Conventions for Genetic Reuse":

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04ws

But what's interesting in this case is that the "encoding" is 
nothing like any of the usual indirect encoding method usually 
discussed.  In fact the encoding *is* a NEAT neural network.  Yet, 
interestingly, it has sufficient power as an encoding to show many 
of the properties that we desire in an effective encoding: Repeated 
parts, symmetry, and a great deal of variation on the same theme are 
all exhibited.  But what about "reuse?"  Reuse *does* occur in this 
encoding, but it's quite different than the usual kinds of reuse 
discussed with respect to indirect encodings, that is, the whole 
network is reused at every pixel, and there is no fractal-like or 
embryo-like expansion process occurs.  Nevertheless, it exhibits 
many of the same properties that result from such processes.  It's 
something to think about.

ken
